title: Motorway Driving: Confident at Higher Speeds
summary: Master lane discipline, joining and leaving techniques, and smart motorway rules for safe high-speed travel.

sections.title: Why Motorway Skills Matter
sections.body: Motorways are statistically the safest roads, but only when drivers plan ahead, use lanes correctly, and stay alert to changing signals.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: National speed limit is 70 mph unless signs show otherwise—always adjust for weather and traffic.
Use the left lane unless overtaking; keep middle and right lanes for passing only.
Hard shoulders are for emergencies; on smart motorways, follow the overhead signs for lane status.

sections.title: Joining and Leaving
items: Use the slip road to match motorway speed, checking mirrors and blind spots before merging.
Signal early when leaving and move into the left lane in good time—do not cross solid lines.
If you miss your exit, continue to the next junction; never stop or reverse.

sections.title: Lane Discipline and Overtaking
sections.body: Plan overtakes early, checking mirrors and blind spots, signalling, and moving smoothly into the next lane. Pass with a safe gap and return to the left lane as soon as it’s clear. Avoid undertaking unless traffic is moving in queues.

sections.title: Smart Motorway Rules
items: Obey red ‘X’ lane closures—driving in a closed lane is illegal and dangerous.
Variable speed limits manage flow; stick to the displayed limit even if lanes look clear.
Use emergency refuge areas if you break down and contact National Highways via the SOS phone.

checklist.label: I cruise in the left lane and only stay in other lanes when overtaking.
I can match speed on the slip road and join the motorway smoothly.
I understand smart motorway signals, including red X, amber warnings, and variable limits.
I know what to do if I break down or miss an exit on a motorway.

practiceTips.label: Virtual practice
practiceTips.detail: Watch DVSA motorway driving videos. Pause to explain why drivers chose certain lanes or adjusted speed.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s slip-road drill
practiceTips.detail: On dual carriageways, practise accelerating briskly up the slip road, checking mirrors twice before merging. The habit transfers directly to motorways.

practiceTips.label: Signal audit
practiceTips.detail: Keep a note of every time you used or missed a signal when changing lanes. Review weekly to tighten your routine.

questions.prompt: Which lane should you normally travel in on a motorway?

options.label: Whichever lane matches your cruising speed
options.explanation: Staying in faster lanes without overtaking blocks traffic and can cause tailgating.

options.label: The left-hand lane unless you’re overtaking
options.explanation: Keep left to maintain flow; use other lanes only to pass.

options.label: The centre lane because it’s safest
options.explanation: Middle-lane hogging is unsafe and can lead to penalties.

questions.prompt: What should you do if a red ‘X’ is displayed above your lane?

options.label: Ignore it if the lane looks clear
options.explanation: A red ‘X’ means the lane is closed—ignoring it risks collisions and prosecution.

options.label: Move out of the lane safely and promptly
options.explanation: Change lanes as soon as it’s safe; the lane may be blocked ahead.

options.label: Slow to 30 mph but stay in the lane
options.explanation: Remaining in a closed lane is illegal regardless of speed.

questions.prompt: How should you use the hard shoulder?

options.label: For short breaks if you’re tired
options.explanation: Use service areas for rest—hard shoulders are for emergencies only.

options.label: Only in a genuine emergency or if directed by the police or signage
options.explanation: Stopping unnecessarily is dangerous and illegal.

options.label: To overtake queues
options.explanation: Driving on the hard shoulder to beat traffic is illegal and unsafe.

questions.prompt: What should you do if you miss your motorway exit?

options.label: Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse carefully
options.explanation: Reversing on a motorway is extremely dangerous and illegal.

options.label: Continue to the next junction and re-plan your route
options.explanation: Stay calm, leave at the next exit, and adjust your route safely.

options.label: Make a U-turn if the road looks clear
options.explanation: U-turns are never permitted on motorways.
